title: ‘Edison’ Review: The Invention of Modernity
text: In October 1929, Thomas Edison was a sleep-deprived octogenarian, deaf as an adder—“I haven’t heard a bird sing since I was twelve years old.” Having sworn off public speaking, he was reluctant to break his silence for Light’s Golden Jubilee, a slickly packaged commemoration of the 50th anniversary of his incandescent light bulb. Yet he could hardly say no when Henry Ford, a fervent admirer, asked him to re-enact the moment of discovery at Greenfield Village—more formally christened the Edison Institute—in Dearborn, Mich. Prominent in Ford’s outdoor museum of historic structures was the relocated New Jersey laboratory...
description: The writer who gave us a masterly biography of Theodore Roosevelt found, for his final work, an equally compelling subject in the oddball genius whose discoveries continue to light our world.
